body_html:
I tried using the standard MNIST dataset, so a dataset issue seems unlikely. You should be able to replicate my problem by trying to classify MNIST images of numbers 1-4. If you set the number of classes in imagenet_data.py as 4, reflecting the size of this dataset, it should cause the error I'm encountering.

The 0 as background class doesn't seem to be causing a problem--tensorflow is able to correctly create and assign int64 labels to each label, and the same problem happens when I use words for labels, not just numbers. Could you explain how the tf.RandomShuffleQueue could cause a problem?

The 0 as background class doesn't seem to be causing a problem--tensorflow is able to correctly create and assign int64 labels to each label, and the same problem happens when I use words for labels, not just numbers. Could you explain how the tf.RandomShuffleQueue could cause a problem?
body:
I tried using the standard MNIST dataset, so a dataset issue seems unlikely. You should be able to replicate my problem by trying to classify MNIST images of numbers 1-4. If you set the number of classes in imagenet_data.py as 4, reflecting the size of this dataset, it should cause the error I'm encountering.

The 0 as background class doesn't seem to be causing a problem--tensorflow *is* able to correctly create and assign int64 labels to each label, and the same problem happens when I use words for labels, not just numbers. Could you explain how the tf.RandomShuffleQueue could cause a problem?
